item.content:encoded:
Watch College Football Free on Fubo

Elevated horror is a film sub-genre that marries together arthouse sensibilities with traditional horror tropes. Prime examples include films like Midsommar and the bad Blumhouse films your friends always pitch for a $5 Tuesday showing. (It’s about a werewolf tearing apart coeds, but it’s also about fatherhood.)

While the horror geeks at CableTV.com are always here for a good flick, we’re also fans of some cinematic junk food. Whether you were looking for a Stephen King-esque bloodbath or a Ghost Ship-level loss under the wire, this weekend’s games had jump scares for every college football fan.

Including this one. (Image courtesy: NBC/Robby Kalland)

For the Week 11 edition of the CableTV.com College Football What To Watch Guide, we’ll investigate how you get a reputation, believe in the long shot, and stay up past our bedtime.

  • CableTV.com’s Game of the Week

CableTV.com’s Expert Viewing Guide: Still can’t watch college football games because of YouTube TV and ESPN’s blackout dispute?

Check out our main How to Stream College Football guide to find the easiest and free YouTube TV alternatives to watch college football games this Saturday. We also cover popular YouTube TV streaming alternatives like Fubo, Sling, and DIRECTV.

CableTV.com’s college football Game of the Week

Watch BYU vs. Texas Tech | ABC

Why you should watch: At the risk of making things awkward next time the writer of this guide visits CableTV.com’s Salt Lake City-based office, we’ll cop to not believing in BYU’s undefeated record for much of the season. But with the Cougars remaining perfect heading into November—combined with second-tier contenders like Cincinnati and Houston losing games—the Big 12 has officially become a two-team race between the Cougars and Red Raiders.

Texas Tech finally got quarterback Behren Morton back last weekend and benefited from five turnovers in a 43–20 win over Kansas State. With players like linebacker Jacob Rodriguez and rusher David Bailey, the Red Raiders’ defense remains elite by the advanced stats.

üìäüèàCollege Football's Most Efficient Teams

üü¢‚¨ÜÔ∏è‚û°Ô∏è Good Offense, Good Defense

üî¥‚¨áÔ∏è‚¨ÖÔ∏è We're Trying Our Best! pic.twitter.com/kNihZXuNjd

— parker fleming (@statsowar) November 3, 2025

BYU’s Utah and Iowa State wins have aged nicely, especially after the Utes stuffed Colorado and Cincinnati into a wood chipper. But if you’re looking to nitpick, the Cougars can be reliant on big plays: BYU’s 45.9% offensive success rate ranks 32nd nationally, and the Cougars converted less than 40% of their third downs against the Cyclones and Utes.

For BYU to pull the upset, they’ll need to drag Texas Tech into a rock fight and get a solid game (on the ground and through the air) from quarterback Bear Bachmeier to keep Texas Tech’s defense guessing.

How to watch #8 BYU at #9 Texas Tech

vs.

Date: Saturday, Nov. 8
Time: 12:00 p.m. ET
Channel: ABC
Location: Jones AT&T Stadium in Lubbock, TX
Point spread: Texas Tech by 10.5

Stream on Fubo

CableTV.com’s top college football games for Week 11

Watch Miami (OH) vs. Ohio | ESPN2
Watch UTSA vs. South Florida | ESPN

Why you should watch: This week’s midweek slate features solid matchups with big postseason implications.

Down in the MAC, the RedHawks just landed a big win over Western Michigan, but the Bobcats are more than capable of creating a logjam atop the MAC standings. Over in the American, UTSA’s coming off a big blowout win against Tulane, and they’ll face a South Florida team that needs to win to stay alive in the conference title race.

 vs.  

Date: Tuesday, Nov. 4
Time: 7:00 p.m. ET
Channel: ESPN2
Location: Peden Stadium in Athens, OH
Point spread: Ohio by 3.5

How to watch UTSA at South Florida

 vs.  

Date: Thursday, Nov. 6
Time: 7:30 p.m. ET
Channel: ESPN

Stream on DIRECTV

Watch Oregon vs. Iowa | CBS

Why you should watch: Over the years, this guide has had its laughs at Iowa’s expense. But to make up for it, CableTV.com’s officially rooting for the latest topic in Big Ten circles. Get in, nerds—we’re making Playoff Iowa happen!

To be clear, 6–2 Iowa’s still running a leather cap-era offense. Quarterback Mark Gronowski has scored more touchdowns on the ground than through the air and has yet to reach 1,000 passing yards for the season. But it hasn’t stopped the Hawkeyes’ ground game from chugging. They rank eighth nationally in rushing success rate, and their leading backs are averaging more than 5.3 yards per carry.

Iowa’s schedule holds up reasonably well, as they held Indiana to their closest win of the season and blew out Wisconsin and Minnesota. The Hawkeyes also close the year with a mostly winnable stretch of games against Oregon, USC, Michigan State, and a Dylan Raiola-less Nebraska. The stats aren’t kind to Iowa’s playoff odds—ESPN’s Bill Connelly and FPI give the Hawkeyes a 6% chance of making the field—but Iowa’s firmly in the bubble conversation with a 10–2 or 9–3 finish.

As for that mostly winnable qualifier: Iowa’s game against Oregon will determine whether Playoff Iowa has legs after this week. Despite Oregon’s name-brand recognition, their recent shakiness is making Vegas a little hesitant—oddsmakers and advanced stats analysts favor Oregon by less than a touchdown. In a postseason that’s swapping Penn State and Clemson for teams like Georgia Tech and Virginia, who wouldn’t want to believe in Weird Kinnick Stadium Magic this year?

How to watch #6 Oregon at Iowa

vs.

Date: Saturday, Nov. 8
Time: 3:30 p.m. ET
Channel: CBS
Location: Kinnick Stadium in Iowa City, IA
Point spread: Oregon by 6.5

Stream on DIRECTV

Watch Duke vs. UConn | CBS Sports Network
Watch Stanford vs. North Carolina | The CW

Why you should watch: The ACC: Your home for Football Mess on (and off) the field this season! Duke snuck past Clemson last week in a frenetic 46–45 win, and they’ll play a fun 6–3 UConn team that’s strung together wins against teams like Buffalo, Boston College, and UAB.

As for Stanford, the 3–6 Cardinals have operated under the radar this season outside of the occasional Andrew Luck sighting, their Florida State win, and interim step-coach Frank Reich.* UNC’s decidedly not been under the radar, but the Tar Heels having a chance to string two ACC wins should give the PR staffer charged with tracking their mentions** a deserved breather.

*He’s just the step-coach until Stanford hires a full-time coach, but he’s also the step-coach who stepped up, folks.

**Belated shoutout to UNC general manager Michael Lombardi for being able to fill two Athletic–affiliated investigations with anecdotes about how terrible he is to work with. (And via FOIABall, he’s also an awful travel buddy.)

How to watch Duke at UConn

 vs.

Time: 3:30 p.m. ET
Channel: CBS Sports Network
Location: Pratt & Whitney Stadium in East Hartford, CT
Point spread: Duke by 8.5

How to watch Stanford at North Carolina

 vs.

Stream on DIRECTV

Watch LSU vs. Alabama | ABC

Why you should watch: Firstly, if we had a nickel for every “traditional heavyweight matchup that got derailed by a coach firing this season,” etc.

But if you’re still looking for reasons to tune in, we’ve got a few ideas:

  1. Consider Kalen DeBoer’s proclivity for swinging between routine wins and wins that are like biking down a roller coaster that’s on fire. The Kalen DeBoer One-Score Win Experience was assembled by a carny with a hand screwdriver, but every missing bolt just means it’s twice as fun.
  2. Despite how things ended last week, LSU’s talent still gives it a chance in any game. (Before the bottom fell out, they even led Texas A&M at halftime.)
  3. In terms of vibes, there’s a Mariana Trench-sized chasm between an interim coach and Brian Kelly.* If UAB can pull off an interim upset after firing Trent Dilfer, imagine what the Tigers could do?
  4. Kadyn. Proctor. Package.

Alabama running the Wildcat formation with 366-pound LT Kadyn Proctor is insane: ü§Ø pic.twitter.com/fIZd0q9hFu

— College Sports Only (@CSOonX) October 11, 2025

*Three final Brian Kelly notes for the season (until he’s hired somewhere else, god forbid):

  • Is “we haven’t really kept in touch” the nicest comment from the Brian Kelly firing post-mortem?
  • The symmetry of LSU Brian Kelly’s feature stories following the same arc as his Notre Dame tenure (Can This Outsider Understand The Culture; I Was A Prick Who Was Losing Games, But Then I Changed My Ways; Everyone Unloads Their Gossip On Me; Now That I’ve Left/Have Been Fired) was remarkable.
  • With Louisiana Governor Jeff “discount tiger importer” Landry doing his best Huey Long impersonation in LSU’s coaching search, the “opposite of your ex” rule is doing yeoman’s work here. (Jon Sumrall’s the sensible choice, which means that we’re two carousel moves away from The Gruden Zone.)

Watch LSU at #4 Alabama

 vs.

Date: Saturday, Nov. 8
Time: 7:30 p.m. ET
Channel: ABC
Location: Bryant-Denny Stadium in Tuscaloosa, AL
Point spread: Alabama by 10.5

Stream on DIRECTV

Watch San Diego State vs. Hawai’i | MWN App/Scripps Sports/Spectrum SportsNet

Why you should watch: Back in Week 0, Hawai’i had a deserved stint in the spotlight thanks to its upset win over Stanford and kicker Kansei Matsuzawa, who’s since gone a perfect 21 for 21 on field goals and 28 for 28 on extra points this season.

Subsequently, they’ve quietly strung together a strong 6–3 season with good wins over Utah State, Colorado State, and Air Force. The Rainbow Warriors will be a tough out for a 7–1 San Diego squad that’s sitting atop the Mountain West standings.

How to watch San Diego State at Hawai’i

Time: 11:00 p.m. ET

item.title: October‚Äôs Netflix Recap: The 5 Shows I Couldn‚Äôt Stop Binge-Watching
item.dc:creator: Sophie Hastings
item.description:
October was a wild month for streaming, but I've narrowed down the noise. From a terrifying true crime to a new season of a political thriller, here are the five Netflix shows I couldn't stop watching.

The post October’s Netflix Recap: The 5 Shows I Couldn’t Stop Binge-Watching appeared first on CableTV.com.
item.content:encoded:
Netflix in October 2025: A month of thrills and chills.

October on Netflix was a lot, right? I swear, just when I thought I was ready to step away from the TV, they dropped another blockbuster season or a terrifying limited series that had the whole internet buzzing. My streaming queue overflowed, but I dove in and came out the other side with a list of recs.

I’m talking about the shows that dominated the Top 10 lists and kept me up way too late. From a long-awaited fantasy return to some genuinely unnerving true crime, here are the five Netflix shows that absolutely defined my October. Trust me, if you missed any of these, you have some serious catching up to do!

Looking for even more picks? Don’t miss TV critic Randy Harward’s weekly What To Watch guide for the freshest streaming recs.

Looking for the hottest entertainment?

Subscribe to CableTV.com’s email newsletter for the latest TV event viewing guides, entertaining takes, and money-saving promotions.

By signing up, you agree to our Privacy Policy & Terms and Conditions.

1. The Witcher Season 4

Okay, let’s address the elephant in the room: the recasting of Geralt. I’ll admit, I went into this season with some fear, but Liam Hemsworth stepped up. The energy felt different, for sure, but Geralt’s story—the battle-weary monster hunter trying to protect Ciri while war ravages a continent—was stronger than ever.

I absolutely loved how this season leaned into the epic fantasy, making it feel grander and darker. Watching Geralt, Yennefer, and Ciri navigate their separate but equally dangerous paths kept me clicking “Next Episode” faster than I’d like to admit. It was the perfect pre-Halloween show.

Where to stream The Witcher

Watch Options

2. The Diplomat Season 3

If you know me, you know I love a fast-paced thriller, and The Diplomat delivered its best season to date. Keri Russell as Kate Wyler is electric, and the stakes this time felt impossibly high. After the shocking end of Season 2, I was on the edge of my seat to see how Kate would navigate the new world order.

The dialogue is still so incredibly sharp, and the combination of global crisis and the messy, complicated relationship with Hal (played by Rufus Sewell) is what makes this show a total winner. It’s smart, tense, and made me feel like I was getting an insider’s look into Washington’s high-stakes power plays. A must-watch.

Where to stream The Diplomat

Watch Options

3. Monster: The Ed Gein Story

Talk about a show that arrived just in time for spooky season. Ryan Murphy’s latest true-crime anthology hit me harder than I expected. I’m usually not a fan of straight-up horror, but the psychological depth of the creepy performance by Charlie Hunnam as the titular Ed Gein made this a morbidly compelling watch.

What interested me most was the focus on the psychological decay and how the crimes impacted an isolated 1950s Wisconsin community. It’s heavy viewing, no doubt, but the meticulous production and unsettling honesty made it an undeniable October obsession for countless viewers, including me. I had to watch a comedy right after just to clear my head!

Where to stream Monster: The Ed Gein Story

Watch Options

4. Nobody Wants This Season 2

After the first season, I was fully invested in Joann and Noah’s hilariously awkward yet sweet journey. This season, they really dove into the reality of making a completely mismatched relationship work, which I found so relatable.

Kristen Bell and Adam Brody have this incredible, understated chemistry that makes every fight and every heartfelt moment feel genuine. It’s the perfect show to binge when you need a break from high-stakes drama. It’s funny, it’s insightful, and it’s the kind of rom-com comfort food that makes you feel good about being a messy adult.

Where to stream Nobody Wants This

Watch Options

5. Selling Sunset Season 9

What is October without a little real-estate drama? Seriously, this show is my guilty pleasure. I live for the over-the-top houses, the designer outfits, and, of course, the completely insane office politics at The Oppenheim Group. Season 9 brought all the drama I crave: new agents shaking things up, professional rivalries reaching new heights, and just general, beautiful chaos.

Watching the agents try to hold it all together while selling multi-million dollar homes is pure, irresistible reality TV gold. If you need to turn off your brain and just enjoy some glamorous cattiness, this is your ticket.

Where to stream Selling Sunset

Watch Options

item.title: How To Watch UConn Huskies Men‚Äôs Basketball in 2025‚Äì2026
item.dc:creator: CableTV.com Staff
item.description:
Watch every dominant performance from UConn men's basketball this season. Our guide has the complete TV schedule, channel lineup, and streaming recommendations.

The post How To Watch UConn Huskies Men’s Basketball in 2025‚Äì2026 appeared first on CableTV.com.
item.content:encoded:
✦ Edited and fact-checked by Managing Editor Mike Strayer, our editorial lead with over 10 years of experience covering TV and sports.

The redemption tour for UConn men’s basketball begins

For a program that just won back-to-back national titles, a third-place Big East finish and a second-round NCAA Tournament exit feels like a failure. That’s the standard Dan Hurley has built in Storrs. Now, the bounce back is on. The Huskies lost key pieces like Liam McNeeley, Hassan Diarra, and Samson Johnson, but they reloaded with a vengeance. The new 15-man roster is a classic Hurley construction: a deep, proven veteran group mixed with elite new talent.

That veteran core is why UConn is the first Big East team since 2005–2006 to land three players on the Preseason All-Big East First Team: Alex Karaban, Solo Ball Jr., and Tarris Reed Jr. They’re joined by 5-star freshmen Braylon Mullins and Eric Reibe, plus a haul of high-impact transfers. The pressure is on to prove that last season was a blip, not a trend, starting with a massive non-conference slate.

I’m going to be blunt: Figuring out what channel the UConn basketball game is on is a nightmare this year. The new Big East media deal is fragmented across five different networks and three separate streaming services. To watch every game, you’ll need FOX, FS1, NBC, TNT, and truTV, plus subscriptions for Peacock and ESPN+. My job is to help you build the right plan so you don’t miss a single minute of this redemption season.

2025–2026 UConn men’s basketball TV schedule

The Huskies’ schedule is loaded. The non-conference portion is a gauntlet designed to build a championship resume, with marquee games against BYU, Arizona, Illinois, and a huge road test at Kansas. The season opener on November 3 will stream on ESPN+.

In conference play, the entire narrative is set: UConn vs. Rick Pitino’s St. John’s. The Red Storm were narrowly voted the Big East preseason favorite, a “disrespect” that has energized the Huskies fanbase. The two rivalry games—at Madison Square Garden on February 6 and the home rematch on February 25—will be critical. That home game against St. John’s is one of eight exclusive Peacock UConn basketball games.

Best TV plans for watching UConn men’s basketball

To watch every single UConn basketball game, you’ll need a fairly complex setup. There is no single service that has it all. You’ll need a “foundational” service that provides the cable channels (FOX, FS1, NBC, ESPN, TNT, truTV) and then supplement it with “essential add-ons” (Peacock and ESPN+).

My top recommendation for the best foundational live TV streaming service is Hulu + Live TV. Its base package is the only one that includes FOX, FS1, NBC, ESPN, TNT, truTV, and ESPN+ all in one place. DIRECTV and YouTube TV are also great options, as they both include all those channels except for ESPN+.

No matter which of those you choose, you must subscribe to Peacock separately, as it offers eight exclusive regular-season games (including the St. John’s home game) and the early rounds of the Big East Tournament.

Find the best service in your area

Enter your zip code below to see your area’s top TV providers.

How to watch UConn men’s basketball FAQ

Where can I watch UConn men's basketball for free?

You can watch games that air on broadcast networks like FOX and NBC for free with a good over-the-air digital antenna. For all other games on cable or streaming, your only "free" option is to use a limited-time free trial from a live TV streaming service like DIRECTV or YouTube TV.

How can I stream UConn basketball without cable?

The new Big East media deal is complex, spreading UConn basketball across multiple platforms. You'll need a live TV streaming service (like DIRECTV or Hulu + Live TV) to get the main games on FOX and FS1. You will also need a separate Peacock subscription for its exclusive slate of conference games.

Can I watch UConn basketball on Peacock?

Yes, Peacock has an exclusive slate of Big East regular-season games, including eight UConn men's basketball games. These games will not be on any other network. Peacock also has exclusive rights to the early rounds of the Big East Tournament.

How can I listen to UConn basketball games on the radio?

You can listen to the UConn Sports Network from Learfield. The flagship station is ESPN 97.9 FM in Hartford. Mike Crispino provides the play-by-play for all men's basketball games. You can also stream the audio broadcast for free on the UConn Huskies app or The Varsity Network app.

Why you should trust us

Our CableTV.com editorial team cross-referenced the official UConn men’s basketball schedule with the channel lineups of every major TV provider. Using those details, we selected our viewing recommendations based on channel availability, pricing, and ease of use.

This guide is updated regularly throughout the season to ensure our information is accurate. To learn more about our methods, check out our How We Rank page.

item.title: When Is the Next Jake Paul Fight? Your 2025 TV Guide
item.dc:creator: Taylor Kujawa
item.description:
Don‚Äôt miss the next Jake Paul fight. We update our guide regularly with The Problem Child‚Äôs upcoming opponents, fight dates, start times, and streaming info.

The post When Is the Next Jake Paul Fight? Your 2025 TV Guide appeared first on CableTV.com.
item.content:encoded:
Heads up! The much-anticipated fight between Jake Paul and Gervonta “Tank” Davis, scheduled for November 14, has been canceled. Still, Most Valuable Promotions and Netflix are planning for a new Paul fight to take place in December 2025.

Whether you love him, hate him, or are just morbidly curious, there’s no denying that a Jake Paul fight is a can’t-miss cultural event. As a longtime sports writer, I’ve watched “The Problem Child” turn the boxing world upside down. But getting a straight answer on how to watch the next Jake Paul fight can be a challenge.

That’s where this guide comes in. I’ve cut through the noise to give you a one-stop shop for viewing details, whether the next bout is a Netflix exclusive or a pay-per-view (PPV) event on DAZN. I’ll break down all the essentials you need to know before the first bell rings.

Get a championship-level internet plan!

Don’t let a slow internet connection knock out your stream in the final round. Enter your zip code below to find the fastest and most reliable internet services in your area.

How to watch the next Jake Paul fight

Well, if you had plans for November 14, you can un-cancel them. The highly anticipated exhibition between Jake Paul and Gervonta “Tank” Davis has been officially canceled. Paul’s promotion company (MVP) announced they were pulling the plug after Davis’s ex-girlfriend filed a civil lawsuit against him, which includes accusations of aggravated battery and kidnapping.

So, where does that leave fans waiting for the next Jake Paul fight? According to a joint MVP–Netflix statement, they are still planning to hold a major event in 2025, just with a new opponent. MVP even posted on social media asking fans who Paul should face in December 2025, so that appears to be the new target window.

This means the “how to watch” part of the equation remains the same, even if the “who” and “when” are up in the air. The next Jake Paul fight will still stream live and exclusively on Netflix. The good news is that, just like the planned Davis fight, this means there will be no extra PPV fee. As long as you’re an active Netflix subscriber, you’ll be able to watch the entire event at no extra cost.

Official statement from MVP regarding the previously scheduled Jake Paul fight on November, 14th. pic.twitter.com/mZNIa4qtJo

— MVP - Most Valuable Promotions (@MostVpromotions) November 4, 2025

Who the heck is Jake Paul?

Jake Paul’s journey from internet prankster to professional fighter is a bizarre spectacle that says more about our culture than it does about boxing. He got his start in 2013 on the social media app Vine (RIP) before becoming a massively successful (and controversial) YouTube star. He even had a two-season stint on the Disney Channel show Bizaardvark.

In 2018, Paul stepped into the boxing ring for the first time, and what started as a side hustle has since become his main event. While his early opponents were a mix of fellow YouTubers and older athletes, he’s now a ranked professional boxer with his sights set on a title. And having signed a multi-year deal with the PFL in 2023, a move to MMA could be on the horizon.

How is the PPV model changing for boxing?

For decades, PPV events have been the cash cow of combat sports. But we’re now witnessing a massive, fan-friendly shift. Marquee events, such as Jake Paul’s fight against Mike Tyson, are moving to streaming services like Netflix. This gives fans complete access for the price of a standard subscription instead of a hefty, one-time PPV fee.

So, are promoters losing money? Not at all. By selling the exclusive rights to a streamer, they’re trading the unpredictable income of PPV events for a massive, guaranteed payout. The Paul–Tyson fight, for example, drew a peak viewership of 65 million concurrent streams on Netflix. That’s a colossal audience that a traditional PPV could never reach, and it’s a major win for growing the sport.

This change isn’t just happening in boxing, either. The UFC is making a similar move with its new Paramount+ deal, which will eliminate the PPV model for its numbered events in the U.S. It’s a clear trend that’s both a win-win for fans and for streaming platforms looking to gain new subscribers.

Want more TV sports coverage?

Subscribe to CableTV.com’s email newsletter for the latest event-viewing guides, entertaining takes, and money-saving promotions.

By signing up, you agree to our Privacy Policy & Terms and Conditions.

What is Jake Paul’s fight history?

Jake Paul’s fight history is a wild ride of marketing savvy and questionable opponents. He made his amateur debut in 2018 before turning pro in 2020. Since then, he’s put together a professional record that’s fairly impressive on paper. But it’s come against a mix of aging MMA legends and boxers that casual fans probably never heard of.

Currently, Paul is on a six-fight winning streak, with his only loss coming via a close split decision to Tommy Fury in early 2023. As of July 2025, he’s officially ranked No. 14 in the world by the WBA, which, believe it or not, puts him in contention for a cruiserweight title shot.

A list of previous Jake Paul fights

Date Opponent Result Method Broadcaster

Nov. 28, 2020 Nate Robinson Paul TKO (2nd) Triller PPV
April 17, 2021 Ben Askren Paul TKO (1st) Triller PPV
Aug. 29, 2021 Tyron Woodley Paul SD (8) SHOWTIME PPV
Dec. 18, 2021 Tyron Woodley (II) Paul KO (6th) SHOWTIME PPV
Oct. 29, 2022 Anderson Silva Paul UD (8) SHOWTIME PPV
Feb. 26, 2023 Tommy Fury Fury SD (8) ESPN+ PPV
Aug. 5, 2023 Nate Diaz Paul UD (10) ESPN+ PPV, DAZN PPV
Dec. 15, 2023 Andre August Paul KO (1st) DAZN
March 2, 2024 Ryan Bourland Paul TKO (1st) DAZN
July 20, 2024 Mike Perry Paul TKO (6th) DAZN PPV
Nov. 15, 2024 Mike Tyson Paul UD (8) Netflix
June 28, 2025 Julio César Chávez Jr. Paul UD (10) DAZN PPV

Upcoming Jake Paul fights FAQ

Will the Jake Paul fight be free to watch?

No, the next Jake Paul fight won‚Äôt be free to watch. It‚Äôll stream exclusively on Netflix, which requires a base subscription. Plans start at just $7.99 a month.

Who‚Äôs on the undercard for the next Jake Paul fight?

The full undercard for the next Paul fight is still in the works, but it should feature several high-profile bouts. I‚Äôll update this guide with the full fight card as soon as Netflix makes the announcement.

Where can I watch Jake Paul fight replays?

You can watch most of Jake Paul‚Äôs past fights for free on YouTube. Typically, full-event replays are also available on the streaming services that originally broadcast them, like DAZN or Netflix.

What‚Äôs Jake Paul‚Äôs professional boxing record?

Jake Paul‚Äôs professional boxing record consists of 12 wins and one loss, with seven of his wins coming by knockout. He also won one amateur fight before going pro.

Why you should trust us

This guide was created by our CableTV.com Sports Editor, Taylor Kujawa, who has skeptically followed Jake Paul’s entire boxing career. From those early days on Triller to his blockbuster fights on DAZN and Netflix, Taylor has analyzed every event and TV deal to give you the most accurate and up-to-date viewing information. Now, you can follow along with the next Jake Paul fight—for better or for worse.

Check out our How We Rank page to learn more about our methods.

Upcoming sports events FAQ

What‚Äôs the biggest sports event in the U.S.?

Many NFL games are among the most-watched sports events in the U.S., with the Super Bowl taking the top spot. Other popular sports events on TV include the College Football National Championship, the Final Four of March Madness, and the Kentucky Derby.

What sport has the longest calendar season?

MLB has one of the longest calendars in major league sports, with teams playing 162 games during the regular season. But other sports like the PGA Tour, ATP Tour, and NASCAR have shorter offseasons. Also, combat sports like UFC and Bellator MMA happen year-round with no set seasons.

What athletic event is held every four years?

Several marquee sports events happen every four years, like the FIFA World Cup, Summer Olympics, and Winter Olympics. Other notable events like the America‚Äôs Cup, Ryder Cup, and World Baseball Classic are also non-annual.

item.title: How To Watch the 2025 MLS Playoffs
item.dc:creator: Taylor Kujawa
item.description:
It‚Äôs survival of the fittest as Major League Soccer (MLS) clubs fight for a place in the MLS Cup Final. The MLS Playoffs will air on MLS Season Pass and FOX Sports networks starting in October, with the grand finale in December.

The post How To Watch the 2025 MLS Playoffs appeared first on CableTV.com.
item.content:encoded:
Stream on MLS Season Pass

I know some people out there think Major League Soccer (MLS) is the annoying stepchild of European soccer. But if you ask me, it’s the playoffs when these talented players really shine.

It’s survival of the fittest as clubs fight for a place in the 2025 MLS Cup Final. The MLS Playoffs will air on MLS Season Pass and FOX Sports networks from October to December, with the grand finale on Saturday, December 6.

This season, the playoffs continue last year’s format of 18 playoff teams. The top seven clubs from the Eastern and Western Conferences qualify for Round One, while the eighth and ninth seeds from each conference must first battle it out in the Wild Card Round.

Keep reading to see what specific channels you’ll need to watch the playoffs and how you can tune in for free.

Don’t miss a single minute of the MLS Playoffs. Enter your zip code below to see the top TV providers available for your home.

What channels are the MLS Playoffs on?

The 2025 MLS Playoffs will stream on MLS Season Pass, with select broadcasts airing on FOX and FS1. MLS Season Pass features English- and Spanish-language commentary, but Fox Deportes also shows playoff games en Español.

Pro tip: International MLS fans can watch the MLS Playoffs on MLS Season Pass, while select games will also air on TSN and RDS in Canada.

MLS Playoffs TV schedule

The 2025 MLS Playoffs begin with wild card matches on Wednesday, October 22, after what will surely be an exhilarating Decision Day on Saturday, October 18. As usual, the playoffs will feature intense action that culminates in the MLS Cup Final—set for Saturday, December 6.

Best TV plans for watching the MLS Playoffs

For my money, MLS Season Pass on Apple TV is the best way to watch the 2025 MLS Playoffs. At $14.99 a month or $9.99 for the remainder of the season, it’s an inexpensive viewing option for anyone with reliable internet. You also get in-depth studio coverage and on-demand access to every game—a great feature if you can’t tune in live.

If you prefer a more comprehensive TV provider, we recommend Hulu + Live TV because it comes with every FOX Sports channel and ESPN+. There’s no way to watch the entire MLS Playoffs for free. But some playoff games air on FOX, which is free to access if you live near a local network affiliate. You only need an over-the-air (OTA) antenna that’s strong enough to pick up the channel’s signal. Then, you’ll get every matchup on FOX—including the MLS Cup Final—without paying a monthly subscription.

Of course, the antenna itself isn’t free. But it’s a one-time purchase that will last several seasons and provide live sports year-round—including MLB, NFL, and Premier League games.

We recommend the Mohu Leaf 50 because its 60-mile range and included amplifier are ideal for clear channel reception. But you’ll first want to enter your zip code on the FCC’s Reception Map Tool to confirm a FOX affiliate is within range of your home.

If you require a wider-range antenna, visit our Best Antennas for Cord-Cutters page for more recommendations.

How to watch the MLS Playoffs FAQ

What channel is the MLS Cup Playoffs on?

The MLS Playoffs stream entirely on MLS Season Pass. But select playoff games also air on FOX Sports channels in the U.S., while TSN and RDS networks show some playoff matchups in Canada.

Where can I stream the MLS Playoffs?

You can stream every MLS playoff game on MLS Season Pass via the Apple TV app. Live TV streaming services that carry FOX and FS1 also provide access to select MLS games.

Does ESPN+ have the MLS Playoffs?

No, ESPN+ doesn‚Äôt have live MLS playoff games. Instead, you‚Äôll need an MLS Season Pass subscription to stream the complete MLS Cup Playoffs.

Does Apple TV have the MLS Playoffs?

Yes, you can watch the MLS Playoffs on Apple TV with an MLS Season Pass add-on subscription. Select playoff games may also stream on Apple TV+.

Why you should trust us

Our CableTV.com sports editor, Taylor Kujawa, examined the best ways to watch the MLS Playoffs by comparing the prices and channel offerings of the most popular TV services. He selected his English- and Spanish-language viewing recommendations based on convenience—focusing on channel availability, pricing, and ease of signing up.

Check out our How We Rank page to learn more about our methods.

item.title: How To Watch the 2025 NWSL Playoffs
item.dc:creator: Taylor Kujawa
item.description:
The 2025 NWSL Playoffs are here, and the latest media deal has spread the games across various broadcasters. Here's our expert guide on how to watch every match on TV.

The post How To Watch the 2025 NWSL Playoffs appeared first on CableTV.com.
item.content:encoded:
The 2025 NWSL regular season is in the books, and the eight-team playoff bracket is set. The single-elimination tournament kicks off Friday, November 7, and culminates with the NWSL Championship on Saturday, November 22. The No. 1 seed Kansas City Current are looking to cap off a record-breaking season with another piece of silverware, while the No. 4 Orlando Pride will fight to defend their 2024 title.

I’ll be the first to admit, as a fan, that watching the NWSL playoffs requires a bit more app-juggling than in the past. It’s not just on one or two traditional TV channels anymore. You’ll find this year’s seven playoff matches split across three different broadcasters: CBS, ABC, and Amazon Prime Video.

To help you follow every moment, I’ve put together this complete guide on how to watch the 2025 NWSL Playoffs. Keep scrolling for the full TV schedule and my expert breakdown of the best (and cheapest) TV plans for tuning in.

Jump to:

  • NWSL Playoffs TV schedule
  • Best NWSL Playoffs TV plans
  • Watch the NWSL Playoffs for free

Upgrade your TV plan for the NWSL Playoffs!

Enter your zip code below to see your area’s best TV and internet providers.

What channels show the NWSL Playoffs?

You’ll need access to at least three different channels and platforms to watch the complete 2025 NWSL Playoffs.

  • ABC (2 quarterfinals, 1 semifinal)
  • Amazon Prime Video (1 quarterfinal)
  • CBS (1 quarterfinal, 1 semifinal, and the NWSL Championship)

Pro tip: Games airing on ABC will stream simultaneously on ESPN+ via the new ESPN Select/Unlimited platform. Meanwhile, all games airing on CBS will stream live on Paramount+ Premium.

2025 NWSL Playoffs TV schedule

This year’s NWSL playoff format is all about high-stakes drama. We’ve got the top eight teams in a single-elimination tournament, and my favorite part of this setup? The top-seeded teams don’t get a bye, meaning every club enters the must-win chaos from the start.

Check out the full 2025 NWSL playoff schedule below to find all game times and channel listings.

Game Date Time (ET) Channels
Quarterfinals
(5) Seattle Reign at (4) Orlando Pride Friday, Nov. 7 8:00 p.m. Amazon Prime Video
(7) Racing Louisville at (2) Washington Spirit Saturday, Nov. 8 Noon CBS, Paramount+
(8) Gotham FC at (1) Kansas City Current Sunday, Nov. 9 12:30 p.m. ABC, ESPN+
(6) San Diego Wave at (3) Portland Thorns Sunday, Nov. 9 3:00 p.m. ABC, ESPN+
Semifinals
TBD Saturday, Nov. 15 TBA ABC or CBS
TBD Sunday, Nov. 16 TBA ABC or CBS
NWSL Championship
TBD Saturday, Nov. 22 8:00 p.m. CBS, Paramount+

Data effective as of post date.

Best TV plans for watching the NWSL Playoffs

If you’ve been watching the NWSL all season, you likely already have access to every playoff channel. But if you’re just joining in, you’ll need a clear viewing strategy. That’s because no single TV service includes ABC, CBS, and Amazon Prime Video.

The most straightforward way to watch every playoff game is to build your own “à la carte” streaming bundle. You’ll need three separate subscriptions: Prime Video (for the Prime-exclusive quarterfinal), a Paramount+ Premium plan (for all the CBS games), and an ESPN Select subscription (which gets you the ESPN+ simulcasts of the ABC games). This entire setup will cost you around $35 a month, and you can cancel everything right after the championship.

There’s also one other, even cheaper way to watch most of the games. Since the ABC and CBS matches are on broadcast TV, a digital antenna can get you six of the seven playoff games for free. I cover that viewing method in more detail in the Watch for Free section below.

Which TV providers carry the NWSL Playoffs?

For those who prefer the traditional cable or satellite route, you’re still in good shape. You’ll need a separate subscription for the Prime Video match, but most major TV providers (like DIRECTV, Spectrum, and Xfinity) carry both ABC and CBS.

To simplify things, I’ve broken down the channel availability for 13 popular services in the table below.

Not every TV provider is available nationwide. Enter your zip code below to find the best NWSL viewing options for your home turf.

How to watch the NWSL Playoffs for free

You have two fantastic strategies for watching the NWSL Playoffs for free: using a digital antenna and taking advantage of free trials.

I prefer using an antenna because I live within range of my local ABC and CBS affiliates, which will show six of the seven playoff games. An antenna is a simple, one-time purchase that gets you the vast majority of the tournament for free. You just need to live within a 70-mile radius of an affiliate and have no major physical obstructions near your home.

Heads up: Before you buy an antenna, I recommend using the FCC’s Reception Map Tool or Antennas Direct’s TV Transmitter Locator to see which channels are available near you.

For the one quarterfinal that streams exclusively on Prime Video, your best bet is to sign up for the service’s 30-day free trial. Live TV streaming services like DIRECTV and Fubo also offer free trials to pick up ABC and CBS if the antenna method doesn’t work for you.

How to watch the NWSL Playoffs FAQ

How many teams go to the NWSL Playoffs?

The top eight NWSL teams, based on the final regular-season standings, qualify for the playoffs. The league expanded its postseason format in 2024 to coincide with the introduction of expansion teams Bay FC and the Utah Royals.

What channel is the NWSL Championship Game on?

The 2025 NWSL Championship will air on CBS on Saturday, November 22, at 8:00 p.m. ET. You can also stream the game live on Paramount+ Premium.

How can I watch the NWSL Playoffs internationally?

Internationally, NWSL playoff matches will mainly stream for free on NWSL+. But the league has global media partnerships in certain countries and territories that may impact NWSL+ access. For example, TNT Sports will air all playoff games in the U.K.

Can I watch the NWSL Playoffs on Paramount+?

Yes, you can watch three NWSL playoff games on Paramount+. The service's higher-tier Premium plan will stream every playoff match that airs on CBS, which includes one quarterfinal, one semifinal, and the NWSL Championship.

Why you should trust us

Our CableTV.com Sports Editor, Taylor Kujawa, has been an avid follower of the NWSL since 2016 and has been covering the league professionally since 2019. For this guide, he combined that deep fan perspective with hours of expert research, cross-referencing the official 2025 playoff bracket with the channel lineups of every major TV provider. Taylor based his recommendations on finding the most cost-effective and convenient ways for you to watch every single match.

Check out our How We Rank page to learn more about our methods.

Game day starts here!

Peacock is a must-have streaming service for soccer fans in the U.S. to watch the English Premier League (EPL). Just under half of the league’s 380 games stream exclusively on Peacock, with NBC match simulcasts also available on the service. But you’ll need USA Network to catch other matches not streaming on Peacock.

To get Peacock, you must subscribe to one of its premium plans—starting at $10.99 a month. Not only will you receive around 175 live Premier League games per season, but you’ll also have thousands of movies and TV shows at your fingertips. As for USA Network, you’ll need a cable, satellite, or live TV streaming plan to pick up the channel.

Keep reading to learn more about how to watch the Premier League in the U.S. We update this guide regularly with the league’s U.S. TV schedule and channel listings to help you tune in.

Jump to:

  • Premier League channels
  • Premier League TV schedule
  • Best Premier League TV plans
  • Watch the Premier League for free

Want more TV sports coverage?

Subscribe to CableTV.com’s email newsletter for the latest event-viewing guides, entertaining takes, and money-saving promotions.

By signing up, you agree to our Privacy Policy & Terms and Conditions.

What channels show Premier League games?

Premier League fans in the U.S. can watch every match across NBC, Peacock, and USA Network. If you prefer Spanish-language commentary, Telemundo, UNIVERSO, and Peacock carry select games en Español.

Some matches may appear on other NBCUniversal networks, such as CNBC, Golf Channel, and Syfy, especially on Championship Sunday. But Peacock often simultaneously streams those games and all matches that air on NBC.

Pro tip: Fans of England women’s soccer can catch many Women’s Super League and Women’s Championship matches on the Barclays WSL and Barclays WC YouTube channels. Some WSL games also stream on ESPN+.

Premier League TV schedule

The 2025–2026 Premier League season began on August 15, 2025, and wrap up with Championship Sunday on May 24, 2026. Keep in mind that all match times are subject to change due to cup competitions and weather, which is why we update this section nearly every week of the season.

Below, you’ll find a list of the upcoming matchday fixtures with U.S. kickoff times and channel listings. You can also visit the official Premier League Matches webpage to see the entire calendar.

Match Day Time (ET) Channels
Matchweek 11
Manchester United at Tottenham Hotspur Saturday, Nov. 8 7:30 a.m. Peacock
Fulham at Everton Saturday, Nov. 8 10:00 a.m. USA Network, UNIVERSO
Burnley at West Ham United Saturday, Nov. 8 10:00 a.m. Peacock
Arsenal at Sunderland Saturday, Nov. 8 12:00 p.m. NBC, Peacock, UNIVERSO
Wolverhampton Wanderers at Chelsea Saturday, Nov. 8 3:00 p.m. NBC, Peacock, UNIVERSO
Bournemouth at Aston Villa Sunday, Nov. 9 9:00 a.m. USA Network
Brighton & Hove Albion at Crystal Palace Sunday, Nov. 9 9:00 a.m. Peacock
Leeds United at Nottingham Forest Sunday, Nov. 9 9:00 a.m. Peacock
Newcastle United at Brentford Sunday, Nov. 9 9:00 a.m. Peacock
Liverpool at Manchester City Sunday, Nov. 9 11:30 a.m. USA Network, Telemundo

Data effective as of post date.

Best TV plans for watching the Premier League

Peacock is an essential part of watching the Premier League in the U.S. Yet, to enjoy every game this season, you must supplement Peacock with a TV provider that carries USA Network.

Fortunately, Peacock is an inexpensive service. Its premium plans start at $10.99/mo., and grant you access to nearly half of this season’s Premier League games. On top of that, Peacock includes thousands of movies and TV shows alongside additional live sports. We’re talking NFL, Premiership Rugby, and WWE events. You even get complete Spanish-language access to the FIFA World Cup and FIFA Women’s World Cup each time those tournaments come around.

The cheapest way to get USA Network is through Sling TV. The live TV streaming service offers the channel in its Sling Blue plan for $45.99/mo. But if you have more room in your budget, Hulu + Live TV also has NBC Sports channels and includes ESPN+ at no extra cost—giving you live FA Cup, La Liga, and Bundesliga games. Unfortunately, you’ll also need Paramount+ in your streaming roster if you want robust EFL Championship and League One coverage.

What TV providers carry Premier League games?

Most cable, satellite, and live TV streaming services carry Premier League games via NBC, CNBC, and USA Network. But as shown in our table below, some providers don’t have any NBCUniversal channels.

Find the best provider for watching soccer

Provider coverage varies by location, so enter your zip code below to see top-ranked options in your area.

Premier League content on Peacock

Peacock has a wealth of Premier League content. It streams around 175 live games and occasionally offers multiview coverage. With Peacock, you can also watch on-demand replays of all 380 league matchups each season. Replays of games that didn’t originally air live on Peacock become available 24 hours after the match ends and are available to stream for 30 days.

Outside of actual games, Peacock is also home to Premier League studio shows, highlights, and docuseries. There’s even a 24/7 live channel called Premier League TV that really comes in handy on transfer deadline days.

What’s great about Premier League TV is that it airs a mixture of U.S.- and U.K.-produced content. This means you’ll get the best of both worlds with NBC Sports and Sky Sports programming. We particularly enjoy The Kelly & Wrighty Show, which features presenter Kelly Cates and Arsenal legend Ian Wright.

Here’s a list of Premier League programs featured on Peacock:

  • The 2 Robbies
  • The Analysis Show
  • The Big Interview
  • The Catch Up Show
  • Fantasy Premier League
  • Goal Rush
  • Headline Makers
  • The Kelly & Wrighty Show
  • The Lowe Down
  • The Men in Blazers Show
  • Netbusters
  • PL Stories
  • Premier League 100
  • Premier League Fanzone
  • Premier League Match Pack
  • Premier League Today
  • The Weekend Preview
  • The Weekend Review

How to watch the Premier League for free

Get Free Local Channels
Editorial rating (4.5/5)
Recommended antenna:
Mohu Leaf 50 ($46.99, one-time purchase†)
Premier League channels:
NBC and Telemundo
Features:
All local broadcast channels
View on Amazon
Read Mohu Leaf review

†CableTV.com utilizes paid Amazon links. Amazon.com Price; $46.99 (as of 7/25/25 11:20 a.m. CT). Read full disclaimer.

You can watch Premier League games free in the U.S. using an over-the-air (OTA) antenna to pick up your local NBC or Telemundo station. Unfortunately, neither channel is available in every corner of the country. But you can use the FCC’s Reception Map Tool to verify if they’re within range.

There isn’t a free way to access Premier League games on Peacock. However, you can sign up for a live TV streaming trial to watch games on NBC and USA Network without paying. Fubo offers a seven-day free trial and provides access to both channels.

How to watch the Premier League FAQ

Is the Premier League free on Peacock?

No, the Premier League is not free on Peacock. To watch live Premier League matches on Peacock, you must subscribe to one of its premium plans (starting at $10.99 a month).

Does Peacock Premium have all Premier League games?

No, Peacock Premium doesn‚Äôt have all Premier League games available to stream live‚Äîbut it does have every game available to stream on demand. Games that don‚Äôt appear live on Peacock will air on USA Network or CNBC for English-language coverage and UNIVERSO for Spanish-language coverage. These games will become available as full match replays on Peacock 24 hours after they end.

Do Peacock ads interrupt Premier League games?

No, ads don‚Äôt interrupt ongoing Premier League matches. You‚Äôll see commercials before and after each half, regardless of whether you subscribe to the ad-based Peacock Premium ($10.99 a month) or the ad-free Peacock Premium Plus ($16.99 a month).

What app has Premier League games?

You can catch live Premier League games on the Peacock app and the NBC Sports app. You‚Äôll need a Peacock Premium subscription to watch Premier League games on the Peacock app, while the NBC Sports app requires you to log in with your TV provider‚Äôs credentials.

Why you should trust us

Our CableTV.com Sports Editor, Taylor Kujawa, has been an avid Premier League fan for over a decade. He deeply understands the main frustration for U.S. fans: the weekly channel shuffle between NBC, USA Network, and Peacock.

To create this guide, Taylor combined his hands-on experience as a Peacock subscriber with research into NBC Sports’ U.S. broadcast deal (which runs through the 2027–2028 season). He also compared Peacock’s value and Premier League game count with traditional TV options.

Check out our How We Rank page to learn more about our methods.

From November to April, college basketball takes over nearly 100% of our headspace—sorry, friends and family. Perhaps you’re in the same boat, so we’re here to help you find the best TV plan for watching your favorite schools battle it out on the court.

Our TV recommendations span from extensive and expensive to well-balanced and reasonably priced. Not every plan will meet your criteria, but we’ll help you weigh the options to get the best value for your money.

Keep reading to explore the best college basketball TV plans—including a list of the main channels you’ll want and how to watch certain games for free. Also, check out our NCAA Basketball Tournament viewing guide, which outlines how to watch March Madness.

Jump to:

  • College basketball channels
  • Best college basketball TV plans
  • Watch college basketball for free

Bring the college court to your home

Enter your zip code below to see your area’s best TV and internet providers.

What channels have college basketball games?

College basketball games appear across many TV networks—especially CBS Sports, ESPN, and FOX Sports platforms. Of course, the best college basketball channels show the matchups that interest you the most. That’s why we recommend visiting your favorite team’s official schedule for the most accurate channel listings.

March Madness: The men’s NCAA Tournament airs on CBS, TBS, TNT, and truTV, while the women’s competition appears on ESPN networks. Visit our NCAA Basketball Tournament guide for a closer look at channel listings and tournament schedules.

Casual fans can get decent NCAA basketball coverage on local channels like ABC, CBS, FOX, NBC, and The CW. But if you want the most games possible, you’ll want a TV plan with your preferred college conference channel and regional sports networks (RSN) like the ones listed below.

Conference channels:

  • ACC Network
  • Big Ten Network
  • SEC Network

Regional sports networks:

  • Altitude Sports
  • FanDuel Sports Network
  • MSG Network
  • NBC Sports regional networks
  • New England Sports Network (NESN)

Stream ACC, Big Ten, Big 12, Pac-12, and SEC basketball

We’ve broken down how you can stream some major college basketball conferences. Spoiler alert: You’ll need a TV provider login at the ready or a subscription to ESPN Select or ESPN Unlimited to access most of these Power Five streaming options.

  • Atlantic Coast Conference: ESPN owns and operates ACC Network (ACCN), which annually offers 150+ live men’s and women’s college basketball games. Using a TV provider login, you can stream ACCN content through the ESPN app. You can also stream ACC on The CW presentations via The CW’s free app.
  • Big Ten Conference: The Big Ten’s latest partnership with CBS Sports, FOX Sports, and NBC Sports offers many streaming options. As usual, you can stream Big Ten Network (BTN) games using the FOX Sports app with a TV provider login. You’ll need FOX’s B1G+ and NBC’s Peacock to watch several exclusive matchups, while a Paramount+ Premium subscription will get you CBS games.
  • Big 12 Conference: Big 12 fans can get many games through Big 12 Now on ESPN+ via ESPN Select. But some Big 12 basketball games also air on FOX Sports networks.
  • Pacific-12 Conference: As of June 2024, the Pac-12 Network stopped all operations across satellite, cable, and streaming providers. Many of the sports media rights for the former Pac-12 colleges were distributed amongst other networks—we advise you to check your local TV guide listings for availability.
  • Southeastern Conference: ESPN operates the SEC’s dedicated channel—meaning you can stream SEC Network content on the ESPN app. But you’ll need ESPN Select/Unlimited or a TV plan with SEC Network to log in and watch those games. ESPN+ via the ESPN Select and Unlimited plans also has a ton of live college basketball from smaller conferences like the Sun Belt Conference.

Best TV packages for college basketball

  • Editor’s choice: DIRECTV ($89.99‚Äì$169.99/mo.)
  • Best for streaming: Hulu + Live TV ($88.99‚Äì$99.99/mo.)
  • Most customizable: Sling TV ($19.99‚Äì$60.99/mo.)
  • Cheapest: ESPN Select ($12.99/mo.)

Don’t miss the next college tip-off

Enter your zip code to explore the best TV providers available in your area for watching college sports.

Editor’s choice: DIRECTV

Editorial rating (4.1/5)
Price:
$89.99‚Äì$169.99/mo.*
College basketball channels:
ACC Network, Big Ten Network, SEC Network, and more
Features:
Wide RSN availability; Genie DVRs (200–450 hrs.)
View Plans for DIRECTV
Read DIRECTV review

Data effective as of post date. Compatible device and internet connection required. Offers and availability may vary by location and are subject to change. See full disclaimer for details.

Pros

  • Every major college basketball channel
  • Wide regional sports network (RSN) availability
  • 3 mos. of free premium channels

Cons

  • 2-yr. contract
  • Bulky satellite dish

Among cable and satellite providers, we recommend DIRECTV for the most non-streaming college basketball coverage. The satellite TV provider has expensive plans, but its two-year price lock and large channel counts are undeniable.

DIRECTV’s CHOICE All Included package ($89.99/mo.) is our favorite because it has a balanced mix of sports and entertainment channels. If you’re targeting RSNs, you’ll need the CHOICE plan or above to get your area’s in-market sports channels. But you should first enter your zip code into DIRECTV’s local RSN lookup tool to verify which RSNs are in your area.

You can also take your DIRECTV plan up a notch by getting the DIRECTV SPORTS PACK add-on ($14.99 per month). It comes with more out-of-market networks and sports channels, including CBS Sports Network and Next Level Sports.

Of course, DIRECTV certainly has its disadvantages. For instance, you must sign a two-year contract and connect a satellite dish to your home. Plus, DIRECTV doesn’t carry beIN SPORTS channels. If beIN SPORTS is a requirement, you’ll want to check out DISH instead.

View DIRECTV Plans

NCAA March Madness Live app

If you already have a cable, satellite, or live TV streaming subscription, you can sign in to the NCAA March Madness Live app with your provider credentials and watch every game in the tournament. It’s a great way to catch live games and highlights while on the go.

If you don’t have a TV provider, you can still use the app’s free three-hour preview—it’s enough time to watch at least one game for nothing.

Best for streaming: Hulu + Live TV

Editorial rating (4/5)
Price:
$88.99‚Äì$99.99/mo.
College basketball channels:
CBS Sports Network, FS2, and more
Features:
85+ channels; unlimited cloud DVR storage
View Plans for Hulu
Read Hulu + Live TV review

Data effective as of post date. Compatible device and internet connection required. Offers and availability may vary by location and are subject to change.

Pros

  • Key basketball networks
  • Unlimited cloud DVR
  • ESPN Select and Disney+ included

Cons

  • Small sports channel lineup
  • Only 2 simultaneous streams allowed

In the cord-cutting age, Hulu + Live TV is our favorite way to watch college basketball. The live TV streaming service doesn’t have an extensive channel lineup, but it still carries essential basketball networks like ESPN, FS1, and CBS Sports Network.

Hulu + Live TV bundles start and include ESPN Select and Disney+ for no extra charge. Having ESPN Select integrated into the Hulu app is a massive perk for college sports fans. Not only do you avoid paying for an additional subscription, but you can also easily navigate between traditional live sports channels and ESPN+ content.

Other great benefits of Hulu + Live TV are its unlimited cloud DVR and My Stuff watchlist. These features allow you to search for your favorite college basketball teams, add them to your My Stuff hub, and record all upcoming games without running out of storage space.

View Hulu + Live TV Plans

Most customizable: Sling TV

Price:
$19.99‚Äì$60.99/mo.
College basketball channels:
ABC†, ESPN, ESPN2, FS1, and more
Features:
50 hr. Cloud DVR; 30+ add-on channels and packages

Read Sling TV review

Data effective as of post date. Compatible device and internet connection required. Offers and availability may vary by location and are subject to change.

†Available only in select markets with Sling Blue. Without ABC, Sling TV subscribers can watch ESPN on ABC broadcasts via ESPN3.

Pros

  • Inexpensive pricing
  • Customizable plans
  • Diverse sign-up deals

Cons

  • Poor local channel coverage
  • Limited DVR space included

Sling TV offers the best value for watching college basketball because it carries many games for a low monthly cost. Its Sling Blue plan is just $45.99/mo. and includes essential basketball channels like TBS, TNT, and truTV.

The biggest downside to Sling TV is that it doesn’t have complete local channel coverage. While ABC, FOX, and NBC are available to Sling TV users in select markets, you won’t find CBS in any of the service’s plans. But missing those channels isn’t the end of the world for sports fans.

Most sports airing live on ABC also stream on ESPN3, an ESPN overflow channel available to all Sling Orange and Sling Orange + Blue subscribers. Several Sling TV deals also include a free HD antenna to ensure you still get every local channel available in your area.

You can get even more college basketball coverage with Sling TV’s Sports Extra add-on for as little as $11 per month. Its channels vary depending on your base plan, but it’s a great way to get conference networks like Big Ten Network (BTN), SEC Network, and ACC Network (ACCN).

View Sling TV Plans

Cheapest: ESPN Select

Price:
$12.99/mo.
College basketball content:
Exclusive live games and on-demand replays
Features:
10,000+ live sports events; full 30 for 30 library
View Plans for ESPN+
Read ESPN Select review

Data effective as of post date. Compatible device and internet connection required. Offers and availability may vary by location and are subject to change.

Pros

  • Inexpensive pricing
  • Rich on-demand sports library
  • Exclusive college conference content

Cons

  • Traditional ESPN networks not included
  • Regional blackouts for major league sports

In recent years, ESPN Select (formerly known as ESPN+) has become one of the prime locations to catch college sports—not just basketball. Getting ESPN Select for free through Hulu + Live TV is excellent for sports fans who want the benefits of ESPN Select on top of a live TV plan. But you can still get ESPN Select as a standalone subscription.

ESPN Select delivers thousands of collegiate basketball games thanks to long-term agreements with over 25 college conferences—including the Big 12, the Ivy League, and the Missouri Valley Conference. In fact, the 2024–2025 college basketball season on ESPN Select will feature more than 3,200 men’s games and over 3,000 women’s games. That’s a lot of b-ball, folks.

View ESPN Select Plans

How to watch college basketball for free

Get Free Local Channels
Editorial rating (4.5/5)
Recommended antenna:
Mohu Leaf 50 ($46.99, one-time payment‡)
College basketball channels:
ABC, CBS, FOX, NBC, and The CW
Features:
All local broadcast channels
View on Amazon
Read Mohu Leaf review

‡CableTV.com utilizes paid Amazon links. Amazon.com Price; $46.99 (as of 7/25/25 11:20 a.m. CT). Read full disclaimer.

An over-the-air (OTA) antenna is one of the easiest ways to get free access to live college basketball games. While the antenna will cost money, it’s only a one-time purchase that will benefit you for many seasons. Plus, you’ll have access to many other leagues throughout the year—including the NBA and WNBA.

Costing from $20 to $60, an antenna will pick up every channel within range. Possible networks include ABC, CBS, FOX, and NBC. Because ABC and CBS are home to NCAA Tournament matchups, an antenna can be convenient for watching March Madness.

We recommend the Mohu Leaf 50 because it can receive TV signals within a 60-mile range. Depending on your location, that should get you the primary local channels needed for college basketball. But you can verify that information by entering your zip code on the FCC’s Reception Map Tool or Antenna Direct’s TV Transmitter Locator.

Pro tip: Another way to watch college basketball without paying is to sign up for a free five-day trial of Fubo. With careful planning and discipline, you could watch a solid amount of basketball before your trial expires. Who knows? You might even like Fubo enough to keep it around for the entire season.

Best ways to watch college basketball

Most TV providers have college basketball games, but the best matchups air on various channels. For instance, CBS Sports, TNT Sports, and ESPN networks show NCAA Tournament games. But you’ll also need access to college conference channels and RSNs to watch the most regular-season coverage. With all of this in mind, these are our favorite ways to watch college basketball this season:

  • DIRECTV is expensive but has bulky channel lineups to satisfy the most diehard sports fans. It has many important college basketball channels, RSNs, and several premium channels to hold you over when basketball isn’t on.
  • Hulu + Live TV is the best streaming option for college basketball. Even with its small channel lineup, you still get the main ESPN and FOX Sports channels. Hulu + Live TV also includes ESPN Select, opening the door to thousands of extra college matchups.
  • Sling TV is an inexpensive alternative to Hulu + Live TV. Its base plans have even fewer channels, but there are more add-ons and sweet deals for new subscribers.

A one-time purchase of a digital antenna will save you money while also getting you local channels like ABC, CBS, FOX, and NBC, which all show a great deal of college basketball.

How to watch college basketball FAQ

How can I watch college basketball without cable?

Most live TV streaming services carry channels that show college basketball games. Sling TV, Fubo, and YouTube TV include crucial sports networks, but we prefer Hulu + Live TV because it has ESPN Select at no extra cost for added basketball coverage.

Does ESPN+ have college basketball?

Yes, ESPN Select (previously known as ESPN+) will show over 6,200 men‚Äôs and women‚Äôs college basketball games during the 2025‚Äì2026 season. The streaming service features coverage from over 25 college conferences, including National Invitation Tournament (NIT) games and simulcasts of the women‚Äôs NCAA Tournament.

Does Peacock have NCAA basketball?

Yes, Peacock will stream around 200 men‚Äôs and women‚Äôs NCAA basketball games during the 2025‚Äì2026 season via the Big Ten, Big 12, and Big East conferences.

Does Paramount+ have NCAA basketball?

Yes, the Paramount+ Premium plan carries 300+ NCAA basketball matchups‚Äîincluding various conference championships and select March Madness games.

Why you should trust us

Our experts spent over 40 hours researching TV providers and testing plans, apps, and other services to determine the best ways to watch college basketball this season. We compared these viewing options by examining prices, channel lineups, and extra features.

To learn more about our methods, check out our How We Rank page.

item.title: How To Watch the 2025‚Äì2026 NBA G League Season
item.dc:creator: Eric Chiu
item.description:
Want to track your NBA team‚Äôs most interesting prospects? Here‚Äôs how to watch NBA G League games this year.

The post How To Watch the 2025‚Äì2026 NBA G League Season appeared first on CableTV.com.
item.content:encoded:
From Scoot Henderson to Khris Middleton, the NBA G League has long been a proving ground for hidden gems and future superstars. It’s often the first home for many developmental prospects, laying the foundation for tomorrow’s NBA talent. The 2025–2026 season, which tips off in November, promises to showcase this rising talent as it runs through April.

Whether you’re tracking that promising draft pick your team sent down or following the high-energy local atmosphere, here’s what you need to know about watching the NBA G League this season.

Score the best internet for streaming basketball

Get the fastest NBA streams with a high-end internet connection. Enter your zip code below to see the best internet providers in your area.

1. Get a live TV service

You can watch the 2025–2026 NBA G League regular season on the following channels and platforms:

  • NBAGLeague.com
  • ESPN+
  • NBA TV
  • The Roku Channel
  • Tubi

If you’re interested in NBA G League games, we’d wager that you’re also interested in regular NBA games. In this case, we’d recommend getting Stream with DIRECTV. Along with features like full cable channel lineups and regional sports network coverage, DIRECTV also includes NBA TV, which will be the home of many NBA G League games.

GET DIRECTV STREAM

2. Sign up for NBA League Pass

Are you stuck on a cable TV plan that doesn’t include NBA TV? NBA League Pass is the easiest a la carte way to add NBA TV to your NBA rotation. The streaming service costs $16.99‚Äì$24.99/mo. and includes NBA TV along with full out-of-market game coverage for the entire NBA season. Plus, you can view League Pass on platforms including PlayStation consoles, Apple TVs, and Google TVs.

Check out our NBA League Pass review to learn more about the NBA’s streaming service.

Get NBA League Pass

Want more TV sports coverage?

Subscribe to CableTV.com’s email newsletter for the latest must-watch sporting events, entertaining takes, and money-saving promotions.

By signing up, you agree to our Privacy Policy & Terms and Conditions.

3. Get ESPN Select or Unlimited

ESPN now has two ways for you to access ESPN+ content. The first, and least expensive, way is with a subscription to ESPN Select ($12.99/mo.). Along with almost every NBA G League game, ESPN Select includes exclusive coverage from top ESPN writers like David Shoenfield, live sports games, and original shows. You can get the service with the Disney Bundle, which includes Disney+, Hulu, and ESPN+.

You can also subscribe to ESPN Unlimited. This service costs $29.99/mo. and features every ESPN-owned channel, ACC Network, SEC Network, and ESPN+. That service is available on its own, or through DIRECTV, Fubo, Hulu + Live TV, Spectrum, or Verizon Fios. Just log in to the ESPN app and put in your credentials. 

Get ESPN+

4. Brush up on the NBA G League schedule

If it’s your first time following NBA G League games, remember that its schedule is formatted differently than the NBA. Here are some of the big dates for the 2025–2026 NBA G League season:

Event Start date
NBA G League International Draft July 8, 2025
NBA G League Draft Oct. 25, 2025
NBA G League Tip-Off Tournament Nov. 7, 2025
NBA G League regular season Dec. 19, 2025
NBA G League Playoffs March 31, 2026

Data effective as of post date.

How to watch NBA G League FAQ

Where can I watch NBA G League games?

NBA G League games typically air on ESPN+, NBA TV, Tubi, The Roku Channel, and the NBA G League website. ESPN+ requires a subscription to ESPN Select or ESPN Unlimited, but NBA TV is available on many cable TV plans and via NBA League Pass.

When does the NBA G League start?

The 2025‚Äì2026 NBA G League action begins November 7, with the Tip-Off Tournament. Then, the 36-game regular season begins on December 19.

Are NBA G League games televised?

Yes, most NBA G Leagues are televised on regional sports networks or over-the-air stations within each team's TV market. NBA TV, ESPN+, The Roku Channel, and Tubi also broadcast occasional games nationwide.

How can I watch the NBA G League Playoffs?

The 2026 NBA G League Playoffs will air across ESPNews, ESPNU, and Tubi. Select games may also appear on regional sports platforms, like the FanDuel Sports Network app.

Why you should trust us

Our CableTV.com senior writer, Eric Chiu, researched and tested various ways to watch the NBA G League on TV. He analyzed this season’s schedule and channel listings. Then, he evaluated viewing options across multiple services, determining his top choices based on game quantity, pricing, and ease of use.

Check out our How We Rank page to learn more about our methods.

Game day starts here!
